articles.title: 📊 Apache ECharts 5.5: The Powerful Visualization Library
articles.description: ECharts’ big selling point, beyond being a well supported Apache-backed project, is its balance of power and simplicity. You can do a lot with it (check out the many examples here) without the code becoming complex. v5.5 enhances its ESM support, adds server-side rendering support, and lets you make incomplete pie charts.
articles.author: Apache Software Foundation

articles.title: 📣 The React Team Shares What It's Been Working On
articles.description: Work on React Compiler has progressed with it now powering Instagram’s prod site ('React 19 Will Be Compiled' goes into depth on what the compiler means for most React devs). We also learn React 19 is on the way and will include breaking changes to support things like Web Components.
articles.author: The React.js Core Team

articles.title: Redwood v7.0: The React + GraphQL App Framework
articles.description: Redwood is a full-stack Web framework that takes an opinionated approach, bringing together React, GraphQL, Prisma, and TypeScript, with a focus on building complete apps rapidly. v7 includes a new observability tool called Redwood Studio, realtime GraphQL features, and more.
articles.author: RedwoodJS Community

articles.title: Node.js's 2023 Summarized
articles.description: Rafael, of the Node.js TSC and Fastify core team, shares a useful update on the evolution of Node.js over the past year, how the team ensures Node is well tested and reliable, changes to Node’s vendor dependencies (of which it gained three in 2023), as well as enhancements to Node’s security and Web presence.
articles.author: Rafael Gonzaga

articles.title: A Guide to Using localStorage in Modern Apps
articles.description: localStorage has been supported in most browsers for fifteen years plus now, so it’s a reliable way to store data client-side, though there are still situations where you wouldn’t want to use it. A good primer, but with a focus on alternative options.
articles.author: RxDB Project

articles.title: How to Set Up a Basic Node Server App with TypeScript in 2024
articles.description: Popular dev educator Jason with a quick tutorial on how to set up a modern Node project with TypeScript, live reloading, and loading in environment variables.
articles.author: Jason Lengstorf

articles.title: ▶  Pac-Man in JavaScript in 1 Hour
articles.description: I felt old when Ania said “if you’ve never played Pac-Man before..” 😅 – nonetheless, she’s back with another of her fantastic, thorough walkthroughs.
articles.author: Ania Kubów

articles.title: HTMX vs React: A Complete Comparison
articles.description: It strikes me as tricky to compare two very different approaches to what will often be distinct use cases, but undoubtedly people will want to weigh them up against each other, so here you go.
articles.author: Antonello Zanini and Dan Ackerson

articles.title: How Qwik Differs From React Hydration
articles.description: Qwik works quite differently to the React approach.
articles.author: Paul Scanlon (The New Stack)

articles.title: Perspective 2.8: Fast Streaming Data Visualization via WebAssembly
articles.description: A data visualization component, well-suited for large and/or streaming datasets, that can be used from both JavaScript and Python. It’s been fun watching this library improve over the past couple of years. The docs have been improved a lot. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Perspective Authors

articles.title: Vuestic Admin: A Vue 3 Admin Template
articles.description: A recently redesigned, modern admin template using Vue 3, Vite, Pinia, and Tailwind CSS. Check out the live demo or GitHub repo.
articles.author: Epicmax LLC

articles.title: 🗓 Tommy's Inclusive Datepicker: A Human-Friendly Date Picker
articles.description: Try out this Web Component on the homepage itself. The user can type natural language phrases like “Next Friday” or “in 30 days” and the picker will move to the correct date. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Tommy Feldt

articles.title: Skeleton: Reactive, Accessible Svelte UI Toolkit
articles.description: A cool feature of the homepage is you can try out the different built-in themes, including dark and light modes, using a drop-down at the top.
articles.author: Skeleton Labs

articles.title: Dax: Cross-Platform Shell Tools for Node
articles.description: Similar to Google's zx but uses a cross-platform shell with common built-in commands so more code will work across platforms. Dax was originally written for Deno but now supports Node too.
articles.author: David Sherret

articles.title: js-tokens 9.0: A Tiny JavaScript Tokenizer
articles.description: A regex-powered ‘almost spec-compliant’ JavaScript tokenizer.
articles.author: Simon Lydell

articles.title: A Sudoku Solver Implemented in the TypeScript Type System?
articles.description: An appropriate use of the 🤯 emoji here, I think!
articles.author: Roy Li

articles.description: 🐢 The Node.js project has unveiled Rocket Turtle, its new mascot!
1 in 5 of the most popular, 'high impact' packages on npm now include ESM.
👾 A 'Frogger' game in 256 bytes? Yes, really. Be sure to View Source.
A visualization of Math.random() distributions of various kinds.
The Deno team has revamped its onboarding tutorials for Deno Deploy, if you want to experiment with JavaScript at the edge.
Bun 1.0.28 – Mostly a bugfix/stability release.
Puppeteer 22.2 – Control Chrome with Node.js. Now on Chrome 122.
Deno 1.41, Rollup 4.12.0, Jest Puppeteer 10.0

articles.title: How To Center a Div
articles.description: What was once a tricky ordeal in CSS is now much easier thanks to lots of new tools — but which one do you reach for? Flexbox, Grid, something else? Josh dives in, and shares the trade-offs between different approaches, and the strategies to use. He notes “this turned out to be way more interesting than I initially thought”. The definitive resource to conclude a long running meme in the Web design world? Let's hope!
articles.author: Josh W Comeau

articles.title: An Update on Apps Distributed in the European Union
articles.description: Last week we shared news that Apple looked to be dropping support for Progressive Web Apps for users located in the EU. That news has now sadly been confirmed in a developer support document.
articles.author: Apple

articles.title: “It’s Official, Apple Kills Web Apps in the EU”
articles.description: Here’s a response to the above news from the Open Web Advocacy group, who are also asking for feedback from developers and businesses who operate online in the EU on how this may impact things.
articles.author: Open Web Advocacy

articles.title: Okay, Color Spaces
articles.description: This is an excellent, fun explainer of color spaces — a worthwhile read if you’re curious about the various color changes coming to CSS.
articles.author: Eric Portis

articles.title: What is Utility-First CSS?
articles.description: A critical view on so-called 'utility-first' CSS, highlighting skepticism towards its practicality, and noting that whilst it may seem appealing it often complicates things rather than simplifies them.
articles.author: Heydon Pickering

articles.title: Creating a CSS-Only DVD Screensaver Animation
articles.description: No, you’ve been staring at this for five minutes waiting for it to hit the corner… Anyway, here’s a detailed look at how this classic DVD animation has been recreated, without JavaScript. All presented with dynamic examples and handy code snippets.
articles.author: Javier Morales

articles.title: 100 Things You Can Do On Your Personal Website
articles.description: Do you have a personal site? If not, maybe consider it and then go through this list. 🧡 IndieWeb
articles.author: James G

articles.title: SVG Flag Icons
articles.description: A collection of over 200 country flag icons with one click SVG code-to-clipboard.
articles.author: Nucleo

articles.title: Marquee: A Beautiful 'Marquee' Component for React
articles.description: Not just for text, which is what we normally associate with the so-called ‘marquee’ effect. You can see some examples here, one of which is a vertical marquee.
articles.author: Erick Hartanto

articles.title: Tempo: An Easier Way to Work with Dates
articles.description: This is a collection of utilities for working with the native Date object. Under the hood, it mines JavaScript’s Intl.DateTimeFormat to extract complex data, giving you a simple API to format, parse, and manipulate dates. Good stuff.
articles.author: FormKit

articles.title: WXT: Next-Gen Web Extension Framework
articles.description: A framework for creating cross-browser extensions. You can target Chrome, Firefox, Edge and Safari.
articles.author: WXT

articles.title: restore-scroll: Restore Scroll Position of Elements on Page Navigation
articles.description: This means not only the <body> element’s scroll position can be restored, but any scrollable element.
articles.author: Kent C. Dodds

articles.title: canvas-size 2.0: Determine Max Area, Height, Width, and Custom Dimensions of HTML Canvases
articles.description: The Canvas element is broadly supported across browsers but there are differences in the size limitations, which this library can determine for you. GitHub repo.
articles.author: John Hildenbiddle

articles.title: Cross My Heart
articles.description: This is an impressive playable 'demake' of arcade classic Frogger (or Crossy Road, depending on your generation!) in just 256 bytes. You’ve got to get the 🖤 up the screen using your arrow keys.
articles.author: KilledByAPixel
